      private double upperBound(ClassesAttrType attr, boolean[][] presentAndFinalClasses)
      If the hierarchy hier is tree-shaped, this efficiently (in linear time) computes the maximal distance d(x, y) over the vectors x and y that correspond to the labels in the hierarchy and are present in the data.
      If the hierarchy is only DAG, then the time complexity is O(squared number of different labels in data).

      • processAttribute

        public void processAttribute(ClassesAttrType attr,
                             RowData data)

      • calculateDist

        public double calculateDist(DataTuple t1,
                            DataTuple t2,
                            ClassesAttrType attr)
        Calculates the weighted Euclidean distance between the two classes in the hierarchy, where the weight of a label is m_HierarWeight^depth. The distance is at the end normalised by the upper bound for this hierarchy.
        Parameters:
        t1 - First tuple
        t2 - Second tuple
        attr - The dimension in which the distance between t1 and t2 is computed.
        Returns:
        Normalised weighted Euclidean distance.

      • computeDepthsOfTerms

        private void computeDepthsOfTerms(ClassHierarchy hier)
        Computes the depth of each term in the hierarchy, which can be DAG or tree-shaped.
        Parameters:
        attr - The attribute, which the hierarchy belongs to.

      • getPresentTerms

        private boolean[][] getPresentTerms(ClassHierarchy hier,
                                    RowData data)
        Finds the indices of the classes in the hierarchy that at least one example belongs to.
        Parameters:
        hier -
        data -
        Returns:
        answer[class index] = true iff at least one example belongs to class.

      • upperBound

        private double upperBound(ClassesAttrType attr,
                          boolean[][] presentAndFinalClasses)
        If the hierarchy hier is tree-shaped, this efficiently (in linear time) computes the maximal distance d(x, y) over the vectors x and y that correspond to the labels in the hierarchy and are present in the data.
        If the hierarchy is only DAG, then the time complexity is O(squared number of different labels in data).
        Parameters:
        attr - Hierarchical attribute under consideration
        presentAndFinalClasses - An array of 3 arrays:
        • [..., is the i-th label present in the data, ...]
        • [..., is the i-th label the most specific for some example in the data, ...]
        • [is the number of different most specific labels in the data at least two]
        Returns:
        max d(x, y) over the label sets x and y in the dataset.

      • upperBoundTree

        private double upperBoundTree(ClassHierarchy hier,
                              boolean[] presentClasses,
                              boolean[] finalClasses)
        Finds the upper bound of the weighted Euclidean distance for a given data. Covers the following cases:
        • any type of tree hierarchy (e.g. line)
        • at least two terms of the hierarchy must be present in the data
        Parameters:
        hier - The hierarchy
        presentClasses - true at that components that correspond to terms that are present in the data
        finalClasses - true at that components that correspond to the deepest term for some example in the data

      • upperBoundDAG

        private double upperBoundDAG(ClassHierarchy hier,
                             boolean[] presentClasses,
                             boolean[] finalClasses)
        We iterate over all pairs of different final classes and return the maximal distance achieved.
        Parameters:
        hier -
        presentClasses -
        finalClasses -

      • findDistantTerms

        private java.util.ArrayList<ClassTerm> findDistantTerms(ClassHierarchy hier,
                                                        ClassTerm root,
                                                        boolean[] presentClasses,
                                                        boolean[] finalClasses)
        Recursively finds the two most distant terms of the hierarchy that represent the final classes in the data, it two such terms exist.
        Parameters:
        root - The current root of the hierarchy.
        presentClasses - see upperBound
        finalClasses - see upperBound
